content.description:
It’s hard to compare this line to anything else of the grade in Colorado, because it’s so unique, but it’s certainly one of the absolute best problems you can find anywhere. Bullet rock, unbreakable holds, an obvious line, and a flat, meadow landing make this climb so special.

Beginning sitting on a pair of slots in the low dihedral. Immediately launch into some very powerful and technical climbing involving heel hooks, toe hooks, and kneebars as the line trends right via several non-holds. Paddle dyno over to jugs in the middle of

Mind the Gap

(yes, it’s the line of least resistance and obvious sequence), and finish directly up the tall, and very punt-able face. Top out at the apex of the boulder.
content.protection: A few pads. It has a flat landing in a meadow.
content.location:
Start in the center of the cave on the lowest jugs in the dihedral. Move up and right to holds on

Mind the Gap

, then climb straight up the line of least resistance to the tallest point of the boulder.

content.description: Mind The Gap is classic at the grade and a popular problem. Start standing on two bad underclings with even worse feet. Make a huge, right cross to a sideways jug, and hold the barn door. Continue left with small holds and fluent body English to a jug gaston at the lip.
content.protection: A few pads. It has a perfect, flat landing.
content.location: On the large overhanging side of the boulder, it starts on a faint arete and works up and left via a line of holds.

content.description: This is an awesome moderate with perfect rock. Start on edges, and work up through sidepulls and crimps to a massive, right hand lunge to the lip. It is not really a dyno but a great problem, alas.
content.location: On the right side of Boulder #2’s slightly overhanging East side (facing the talus).
